column1: Wageningen (Dutch pronunciation: [ˈʋaːɣənɪŋə(n)] (listen)) is a municipality and a historic town in the central Netherlands
column2: in the province of Gelderland. It is famous for Wageningen University
column3: which specialises in life sciences. The municipality had a population of 38
column5: of which many thousands are students from over 150 countries.

column1: Wageningen is situated on the north bank of the Nederrijn (the Dutch portion of the Lower Rhine) part of the Gelderse valley (Dutch: Gelderse Vallei) and the Veluwe
column2: of which the southwest hill is called the Wageningse Berg. Wageningen can be reached by car from highways A12 via the N781
column3: A15 via the N233 and N225
column5: and from the Ede-Wageningen railway station via a 20-minute bus drive to the Wageningen central terminal (see below).

column1: Topographic map of the municipality of Wageningen

The oldest known settlements in the Wageningen area were located north of today's town centre.  They were mentioned as early as 828. During the early Middle Ages a small church was built on the hill east of the town. Several wood farms have been found near the top of the hill. In the twelfth century people settled at what is currently the Bergstraat. Close to Hotel de Wereld a stone floor has been found dating back to this period. After the construction of a dike to protect the city from the acidic water from the moors that then occupied the Gelderse Vallei (the current Hoogstraat)
column2: the oldest part of the present city was built to the south. The parts of the city north of the Hoogstraat were built later. Wageningen received city rights in 1263. The city was protected by a city wall and a moat
column3: and in 1526 a castle was built. The castle was dismantled during the 18th century
column4: but the foundations of three of the towers and part of the wall remain visible today.

column3: and institutions of Wageningen suffered greatly during World War II. The central part of Wageningen was destroyed by artillery fire soon after the German invasion of the country in May 1940. The town is also famous for its role at the end of the war: Wageningen was the site of the surrender of German General Johannes Blaskowitz to Canadian General Charles Foulkes on May 5
column5: officially ending the war in the Netherlands. The generals negotiated the terms of surrender in the Hotel de Wereld
column6: near the center of the city. Now
column7: each year on the 5th of May
column9: Wageningen hosts a large festival to celebrate the liberation. On this occasion
column10: veteran soldiers parade through the city and are honoured for their service
column12: 000 people  visit the pop-podia around the city.

column1: In 1918 the town acquired its first institution of higher education
column3: which was based on the previous agricultural college founded in 1876
column4: and which later became Wageningen University.  This initiated the development from a small historical town into a modern technological community
column5: a process which still continues today.

column2: Wageningen is also the central city in Food Valley
column3: the Dutch food & nutrition cluster concentrated around WUR
column5: companies and facilities in the food & nutrition field. Food Valley is regarded as the largest food & nutrition Research & Development cluster in the world. One such firm
column7: a biotechnology company in Wageningen developed AFLP in the early 1990s and collaborated with Beijing Genomics Institute to sequence the entire genome of Brassica napus.

column1: The city had its own professional football (soccer) club
column3: which won the KNVB-beker (KNVB Cup) twice. The club went bankrupt in 1992 and played its last match in May 1992 against NAC Breda.

column1: The city is also home to the largest Korfball club in the country
column3: originally known as Vada before merging with two other local clubs.

column1: Wageningen is situated on the N225 provincial road
column2: between Driebergen and Arnhem. The N781 provincial road connects Wageningen to the A12 national highway
column3: to the north of the city. A small ferry (for cars
column5: and pedestrians) crosses the Nederrijn to the south of the city
column7: drivers can connect to the A15 national highway

column1: Several firms provide public bus service in and to Wageningen. From the Wageningen central bus terminal
column8: and the Ede-Wageningen railway station. Further connections via bus
column9: including to the Hoge Veluwe National Park and the Kröller-Müller Museum
